persona.name: Quinn Garcia

occupation.title: Part-time barista / retail associate; Freelance visual designer and social media content creator
occupation.organization: Local independent coffee shop + assorted freelance clients (small businesses, Twitch streamers, local bands)
occupation.description: Quinn splits time between morning and evening shifts at a busy neighborhood coffee shop (preparing drinks, operating POS, opening/closing duties, light inventory) and freelance design work done evenings and weekends. At the shop they are responsible for customer service, latte art basics, training new hires on drink recipes, and handling social media posts when requested. Freelance work includes logo sketches, Twitch overlays, social banners, simple motion graphics, and occasional paid commissions for posters. Skills used daily: Adobe Photoshop/Illustrator, Canva, basic Premiere/CapCut editing, file prep for print, client communication, time-blocking between shifts and deadlines. They struggle most with inconsistent income, negotiating rates, and marketing themselves beyond word-of-mouth and Discord/Twitter (X) contacts.

persona.residence: Los Angeles, California (urban neighborhood, rents a small one-bedroom)
persona.education: Some college: Associate of Applied Science in Graphic Design from a community college in Los Angeles. Completed core classes in typography, digital illustration, branding, and web basics. Took elective courses in media studies and introductory psychology. Left with transferable credits and portfolio pieces; considered continuing to a bachelor's but delayed due to finances and work.
long_term_goals: Build a stable freelance design business with regular clients so I can support myself without a day job.
Buy or co-own a small condo or affordable housing unit in an LA-adjacent neighborhood within 8-12 years.
Quit precarious service shifts and transition to steady, remote creative work full time.
Be emotionally stable and consistent in friendships and relationships; reduce chronic anxiety to a manageable level.
Travel to at least five countries in my twenties (priority: Mexico, Japan, Portugal, Canada, Costa Rica) to visit friends and study creative communities.
Publish a small zine or visual art book featuring personal work and queer/Latinx artists within five years.
Develop healthier sleep and exercise routines that persist beyond occasional bursts of motivation.
Build an emergency savings equal to three months of expenses and pay down existing student/credit debt.
Be known as a reliable, modestly paid designer who gives good art direction and meets deadlines.
Stay politically informed and work locally on issues around affordable housing and gig-worker protections.
persona.style: Casual, layered, and expressive. Clothing mixes thrifted band tees, oversized hoodies, and more tailored thrifted blazers for interviews or client meetings. Talks quickly when excited, soft voice when anxious; uses California-ish vernacular with occasional Spanglish phrases around family and close friends. Texting style is emoji-rich and meme-forward (reacts with GIFs and voice notes). Hands move while describing things; has a small nervous laugh when flustered. In-person manner is friendly but guarded — quick to smile, slow to trust. Prefers first-name basis; defaults to they/them but clarifies pronouns casually. Likes to keep visible cues (a small enamel pin collection on jackets, a single ear piercing with a tiny hoop) that signal creative identity. Often chews the inside of their cheek when concentrating and taps their foot to the rhythm of music when nervous.

traits: Curious and visually oriented — notices small design details other people miss.
Sociable in small groups; more energetic at night with gamer friends.
Financially anxious — thinks about rent and inflation constantly.
Resilient but prone to procrastination when overwhelmed.
Witty and sarcastic in conversation; uses humor to defuse tension.
Conscientious about commitments considered important; lax about low-priority tasks.
Empathetic and protective toward close friends, especially other queer people.
Sensitive to criticism, sometimes broods after negative feedback.
Adaptable — can pivot workflow between coffee shop rush and last-minute client needs.
Idealistic about community and fairness, skeptical of institutions.
Prefers informal leadership; comfortable organizing small, ad-hoc groups or jams.

big_five.openness: High (82/100). Enjoys new art, experimental games, indie music, alternative cuisines, and trying different workflows.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-Low (45/100). Shows bursts of organization around deadlines but struggles with routine maintenance and long-term planning.
big_five.extraversion: Medium (55/100). Energized by small social circles and online communities; drains from large crowds for long periods.
big_five.agreeableness: Medium-High (68/100). Cooperative, kind to friends and coworkers, will advocate for others but avoids unnecessary conflict.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High (70/100). Experiences frequent anxiety about money, future, and performance; can be moody under stress.

interests: Video gaming (primary leisure): enjoys narrative-driven indies, competitive co-op titles, occasional AAA single-player games.
Streaming culture: follows a handful of Twitch streamers and uploads short clips to TikTok.
Graphic design and illustration: experimental color palettes, poster design, zine-making.
Music: indie rock, lo-fi hip hop for working, reggaeton and Latin alternative for social settings.
Late-night cafés and diners for people-watching and sketching.
Streetwear and vintage fashion hunting at thrift stores.
Zine culture and small-press art shows.
Memes and internet subculture (Discord, Reddit, Twitter/X).
Community activism around rent and small business preservation.
Photography with a film-look editing style.
Cooking simple, comforting recipes learned from family.
Public transit and biking for short trips; prefers not to own a car.
Board game nights with friends on weekends.
Watching esports and enjoying the social commentary more than the competition.
DIY craft nights and swap meets.
Tattoo appreciation and design ideas.
Minimalist apartment decorating using thrift finds.
Podcast listening: true crime occasionally, design/business podcasts often.
Learning Spanish design terminology to better communicate with family.
Online marketplaces for selling secondhand gear.
favorite_games_and_genres: Indie narrative: games like 'Oxenfree', 'Night in the Woods', 'Kentucky Route Zero' — values story and atmosphere.
Co-op multiplayer: 'Overcooked'-style chaos for social nights.
Roguelikes: enjoys short runs and incremental progression.
Competitive FPS occasionally with friends (moderate skill level).
Sim/management games for chill evenings (city builders, Stardew-adjacent experiences).
Visual novel/choice-driven games for creative inspiration.
gaming_platforms_and_habits: Primary: PC (modest laptop + external monitor in a small desk setup).
Secondary: Nintendo Switch for portable co-op.
Plays mostly at night after shift and on days off.
Streams sometimes to a small audience; records highlight clips for social sharing.
Joins Discord servers and values community-run tournaments and server events.
Spends time customizing overlays and emotes; designs graphics for the community.
food_and_drink_preferences: Favorite coffee: oat milk cortado with a touch of cinnamon.
Likes casual Mexican food—birria, tacos al pastor, and occasional homemade tamales (family recipe).
Snacks while gaming: plantain chips, spicy peanuts, or a quick microwave quesadilla.
Comfort meals: arroz con pollo, ramen, and big bowls of soup on low-energy days.
Avoids heavy red meats most of the time; experiments with vegetarian recipes.
Enjoys late-night street food and food trucks near the neighborhood.
Prefers small, independent cafés over big chains, but will go to a chain for convenience.
Enjoys trying regional beers and local craft seltzers occasionally.
music_and_media: Favorite artists: alternates between indie acts, Bad Bunny/reggaeton crossover, and mellow hip hop playlists.
Likes curated playlists for different tasks: focus playlists for design, energetic playlists for gym/walks, and nostalgic playlists for downtime.
Frequently watches short-form video for humor and learning quick editing tricks.
Reads longform essays occasionally on Substack and Medium about culture and housing.
socializing_and_nightlife: Prefers small gatherings, house show concerts, and casual bar nights with friends.
Attends queer-friendly events and pop-up markets.
Uses dating apps sporadically; likes laid-back coffee or arcade dates.
Often organizes low-cost hangouts: potlucks, game nights, or thrift-hunting outings.
Enjoys nightlife primarily as a socializing mechanism rather than heavy clubbing.
tech_and_media_use: High daily screen time: social media for 2-4 hours, streaming or gaming 3-5 hours, work-related screen time 4-6 hours.
Smartphone-first internet access; relies on phone for messaging and light editing.
Favorite apps: Discord, Twitter/X, Instagram, TikTok, Procreate Pocket, Lightroom Mobile, Canva.
Subscribes to one streaming video service (Netflix or Hulu) and an additional gaming subscription or Stadia-like platform occasionally.
Keeps a small collection of bookmarked tutorials and templates for quick client work.
likes: Affordable local coffee shops with creative vibes.
Late nights with friends playing co-op games and ordering tacos.
Small, practical tattoos and personal jewelry.
Collaborative creative projects and zine swaps.
Bargain hunting at thrift stores and flea markets.
Podcasts about design and the gig economy.
Tools and templates that speed up repetitive design tasks.
dislikes: Sudden spikes in rent or utility bills (inflation anxiety).
Poorly moderated online communities that allow harassment.
Long, unpaid internships and exploitative freelance offers.
Car-centric city planning and prohibitive parking fees.
High medical costs and opaque billing practices.
Complicated tax forms and inconsistent 1099 paperwork.
Being told to 'just hustle' when underpaid.
Cold corporate chain coffee shops with no character.
Cities that prioritize tourist dollars over long-term residents.

beliefs: Inflation is a very big problem — it’s squeezing rent, groceries, and freelance pricing; things feel less affordable every month.
Local small businesses and independent creatives keep neighborhoods humane; they deserve subsidies and protections.
Housing should be more affordable; rent control (with smart design) helps people stay in communities.
Gig and freelance workers need better legal protections, clearer contracts, and easier access to benefits.
Student debt is a heavy burden that limits creative and economic mobility; there should be more relief options.
Universal basic healthcare or affordable options would greatly reduce financial anxiety for people like me.
Climate change is real and urgent; urban planning should favor public transit and biking infrastructure.
Public transit improvements would dramatically improve my daily life and reduce dependence on expensive car ownership.
Cultural spaces (zines, DIY shows, community centers) are essential and should be supported through grants.
Art and design are legitimate careers even when society undervalues them financially.
Education should be more accessible and practical; community colleges are underrated.
Debt collectors and aggressive billing practices are predatory and should be regulated more strictly.
I’m skeptical of large institutions (big banks, big tech, big landlords) — they often prioritize profit over people.
Small, local political engagement (tenant unions, neighborhood councils) can create meaningful change.
People should be allowed to define their own gender and pronouns without being policed in informal settings.
Privacy matters: platforms should give clearer controls and limit surveillance advertising.
Streaming and creator economies are double-edged: they allow independence but often normalize micro-exploitation.
Designers should be paid fairly and not rely on speculative or 'exposure' deals.
Mental health care needs to be affordable and less stigmatized; anxiety is common and treatable.
Voting matters locally — city council and school board decisions often affect daily life more than national politics.
Immigration is a human issue; families should not be split and contributions of immigrant communities should be respected.
Accessibility in events and online spaces is important and often overlooked in grassroots communities.
Police overreach in some contexts harms community trust; alternatives should be explored for nonviolent issues.
Affordable internet access should be considered a public utility.
Community gardens and local food co-ops are worthwhile and help with food security.
Taxes should be fairer; wealthy individuals and corporations should shoulder more of the public burden.
Creative work is emotionally taxing; unpaid emotional labor within friendships and community should be recognized.
I don’t want kids right now (and possibly not ever) — that should be an accepted life choice.
Representation in media matters: seeing queer and Latinx creators helps younger people feel seen.
Inflation and economic pressure disproportionately harm young people entering the workforce today.
There is value in mutual aid and neighbor-to-neighbor support when institutions fail.
skills: Proficient in Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop for logo and poster design.
Comfortable with Canva for quick client deliverables and social media templates.
Basic motion graphics and video editing using Premiere and CapCut for short streaming clips.
UI/UX awareness: can create simple web banners and Twitch overlays; understands basic responsive considerations.
Hand-sketching and concept thumbnails for rapid ideation.
Decent copy-editing and social caption writing tailored to target audiences.
Customer service skills developed from barista/retail role: conflict de-escalation, upselling gently, managing POS errors.
Time-blocking and juggling multiple small projects; familiarity with Trello/Notion for project tracking.
Light HTML/CSS familiarity for troubleshooting simple website issues (enough to edit templates).
Basic accounting for freelancers: invoicing, tracking expenses, using simple bookkeeping apps (e.g., Wave or QuickBooks Self-Employed).
Comfortable speaking and presenting to small groups; pitches branding concepts to clients.
Simple camera and smartphone photography for social content and portfolio images.
Community building on Discord: moderation basics, event scheduling, role management.
Comfortable creating emotes and simple pixel art for streamers.
Adaptable to new creative tools and fast at following tutorials to fill skill gaps.

general: Text-first communicator: prefers DM/Discord messages and short voice notes to long phone calls.
Checks bank app multiple times a week and budgets obsessively in spreadsheets when worried about bills.
Uses habits of 'batching'—blocks out 2-3 hour sessions for client work to make up for part-time job hours.
Often brings a sketchbook to work to draw during slow periods or while on break.
Shows up early to morning shifts to pick good shifts and prep; occasionally swaps shifts for friends.
Uses humor and sarcasm to smooth awkward customer interactions.
Tends to avoid in-person networking events unless it's a small, themed meet-up.
Regularly backs up work to cloud storage but occasionally forgets to sync external drives.
Sends quick, informal invoices but sometimes delays follow-ups on late payments because of discomfort asking for money.

morning: Wakes between 7:30–9:30 AM depending on whether they have a morning shift.
Skips heavy breakfast on rushed days; usually eats a banana or toast and drinks black coffee on the way.
Checks messages and Discord while brushing teeth, glances at the day's schedule and client deadlines.
Does a short 10-minute stretch or breathwork most mornings when not pressed for time.
workday: For barista shifts: arrives 20 minutes early, helps open, preps milk and pastries, keeps a running mental list of restocks.
During slow cafe hours, sketches flyer ideas, edits a short clip for a client, or posts a pre-scheduled Instagram story.
On freelance days: sets a 25/5 Pomodoro rhythm for focused design sprints, answers client emails during 30-minute midday blocks.
Takes hydration seriously during shifts; tends to drink more water when stressed.
evening: After closing shifts, decompresses with a 30–60 minute gaming session or watches a couple of episodes while eating dinner.
If a deadline is close, does night editing sessions from 9–1 AM with intermittent breaks.
Posts to social accounts 2–3 times a week, schedules content, responds to client comments in the evening.
Winds down with music playlists and light reading before bed, tries to avoid doomscrolling but sometimes succumbs.
weekend: Weekends are dedicated to longer freelance blocks, thrift store runs, meeting friends for lunch, or attending a neighborhood market.
Often hosts or attends a small game night on Sunday with 3–5 friends.
Allocates a chunk of a weekend to administrative tasks: invoices, taxes, and creative brainstorming.
Sometimes volunteers at local zine swap events or helps set up pop-up art shows.

physical.general_health: Generally healthy and active enough for city life. Experiences occasional mild asthma (exercise-induced) controlled with an inhaler during rare attacks.
physical.sleep: Irregular sleep: often stays up late working or gaming; aims for 7–8 hours but frequently gets 5–6 on work nights.
physical.vision_and_hearing: Normal hearing; wears non-prescription blue-light filtering glasses for screen work; no major vision corrections beyond occasional contacts.
physical.diet_and_exercise: Mostly home-cooked or cheap takeout meals; inconsistent exercise—short walks or occasional runs, prefers cycling to a gym membership.

mental.diagnoses_and_treatment: Mild-to-moderate generalized anxiety; has used a sliding-scale therapist a few times and found talk therapy helpful. Not currently on medication but open to medication if a provider recommends it.
mental.coping_strategies: Breathwork, journaling, playlist curations, leaning on a close friend group for check-ins. Finds community and creative flow therapeutic.
mental.stress_triggers: Unpaid bills, unclear client scope, last-minute schedule changes at the cafe, and family money conversations.
mental.substance_use: Occasional cannabis socially; minimal alcohol, mostly social and not heavy. Avoids daily substances.

health.medical_history_summary: No chronic illnesses beyond mild asthma and anxiety. No major surgeries. Up-to-date on basic vaccinations. Has dental anxiety and sometimes delays dentist visits due to cost.

relationships.name: Parents (Luz and Marco Garcia)
relationships.description: First-generation immigrants living in the San Gabriel Valley. Supportive but worried about financial stability. Speak Spanish at home; Quinn code-switches. They emphasize practical career choices, which sometimes causes tension.

relationships.name: Older cousin - Daniela (27)
relationships.description: A mentor-like figure who lived with Quinn briefly and helped with job leads. Works in nonprofit arts programming and inspires Quinn’s community work.

relationships.name: Close friend group (3–6 people)
relationships.description: A mixed group of queer and ally creatives and gamers who meet weekly for game nights, thrift runs, and occasional gigs. Key confidants for emotional support and project feedback.

relationships.name: Casual dating contacts
relationships.description: Sporadic dates through apps and mutual friends. Prefers coffee dates, arcade nights, or low-pressure walks. Not seeking marriage or children at present; values emotional compatibility and respect for pronouns.

relationships.name: Coffee shop coworkers
relationships.description: Many casual acquaintances; a few close coworkers who swap shifts and cover for emergencies. Often social but not deeply intimate relationships.

relationships.name: Freelance clients and streamer collaborators
relationships.description: Professional relationships maintained via Discord and email. A couple of recurring clients (local band, streamer squad) provide steady small work.

other_facts: Single and has no children (primary constraint satisfied).
Uses they/them pronouns publicly and corrects politely if misgendered; family mostly uses their given name and tries to adapt.
Rent is a major monthly stressor; currently pays around 30-40% of income toward rent, more when freelance slows.
Has an undergraduate-level portfolio website showcasing posters, stream overlays, and zine spreads.
Owns a modest laptop (3-year-old midrange model), an external monitor, a drawing tablet (medium), and a secondhand DSLR used primarily for social content.
Has two small tattoos: a simple outline crescent behind the left ear and a tiny coffee cup on the wrist.
First job was a retail cashier at age 16; learned POS systems and basic inventory then.
Grew up bilingual (English/Spanish) and uses both languages regularly when at home or with family.
Was active in high school art club and helped put together a small show in the senior year.
Keeps an emergency binder with scanned copies of important documents and a folder for tax receipts.
Has overdue student loans but modest; also carries some credit-card balance from emergency expenses.
Has a close memory of a summer road trip to San Diego with cousins that sparked interest in zine culture after stopping at an indie bookshop.
Volunteered once a month at a local community arts workshop teaching teens basic design and poster-making.
Once had a design internship that was unpaid; it taught important technical skills but left a bad taste regarding unpaid labor.
Enjoys making playlists for friends and curated mixtapes for people moving away.
Owns a beloved scratched-up sketchbook passed down from a teacher, keeps it for sentimental reasons.
Is small-business cautious—reads reviews and prefers to support mom-and-pop places even when more expensive.
Has experienced mild burnout twice: once in college during finals and again a year ago juggling too many freelance jobs.
Has a low-cost sewing machine and occasionally repairs clothing or customizes thrift finds.
Keeps a foldable bike in the apartment for short commutes and grocery runs.
Uses a small ring light and cheap microphone for occasional streaming and client calls.
Was once featured in a local zine for a poster project and still frames that copy in the apartment.
Has a minor fear of flying but is willing to travel; prefers road trips when possible.
Maintains a spreadsheet of recurring monthly expenses and expected freelance invoices to manage cash flow.
Has a reliable friend who exchanges favors (childcare for them, pet-sitting for friend) in a mutual support arrangement.
Recently joined a local tenant association to learn more about renters’ rights.
Has a mutual-aid mentality: participates in neighborhood fundraisers and clothing swaps.
Plans to get an affordable health clinic membership for therapy sessions if income permits.
Has a wishlist of gear upgrades: a better drawing tablet, an ergonomic chair, and a more powerful laptop.
Prefers practicality in possessions: quality headphones, a sturdy backpack, and a thermos are essentials.
Has small superstitions: always places a specific enamel pin on the left side before a client call for confidence.
Keeps an archive of old design work to track progress and to show potential clients a development story.
Learned basic money management from a parent who emphasized saving but lacked formal financial education resources.
Kept a small bonsai plant for three years—considers it a symbol of their persistence in care despite busy life.
Once organized a neighborhood game tournament that raised a small amount for a local food bank.
Has seasonal rituals: switching to darker palettes in design work during fall and baking a family recipe for Dia de los Muertos.
Collects small enamel pins and swaps them with friends at events as a low-cost creative hobby.
Was briefly part of a student radio collective hosting an hour-long show about indie games and music.
Finds that walking around the block and taking photos clears creative blocks more reliably than forcing work.
Uses a laundromat down the street where they often bump into the same neighbors and exchange small talk—values that micro-community.
